content: <div>
Sidelined
<div>
I still remember the day I wore my first official jersey in the NFL—number 4 for the
Detroit Lions. This was a long way from playing College ball. I had never dreamed of an
NFL career but most of the guys in camp had been laser focused on this goal for years.
Tensions ran high as players sought to impress the coaches and gain a spot on the final roster.
In the NFL some players think the “right stuff” means never showing weakness, and enduring pain
and injury to get the job done on the field at all costs. The pressure to perform was enormous.
During the second week of practice, I was running a long route down the sideline and turned to
catch a pass when I felt it—a pull in my left hamstring. I winced and stumbled to the grass. The
trainer witnessed the fall and he pulled me out immediately to begin treatment. Pulled hamstrings can
take as long as a year to heal, but I only had a few weeks at the most to recuperate.
By the end of July I was training again. I was not fully healed. I knew it intellectually, but
the coaches were looking for performance. I didn’t want to appear to slack off or use my injury as an
excuse. I felt I had to give it my all. I got through the preseason, playing well, despite being in
considerable pain at times.
A few days after our fourth preseason game, on a Tuesday morning, there was a knock on the door.
<div>It was the final week of cuts. My roommate was a rookie defensive back from the University of
Colorado. Playing in the NFL had been his life’s goal. We heard the knock and we both knew what was coming.
The only question that remained was, “Who?”
Both of us were cut.
<div>I was on a plane home to Lynchburg that afternoon.<div>
<div>I got a second chance at the NFL. The Dallas Cowboys picked me up as a free agent the following
spring. Things went well and I adjusted to a new team. But like that knock on the door, it only takes
a moment for everything to change...
<div>I was out on the practice field with Danny White to catch a few warm-up throws when Coach Tom Landry
stepped onto the field.
<div>Danny changed the pace and signaled for me to go long at full speed. I took off, turning it into high gear.
I never caught that pass.
<div>
My hamstring failed again that day, sending me to the grass in pain.
I recovered fully from the injury, but the Cowboys cut me from the roster.
<div>
It was a turning point in my life. I was disappointed to see my new dream of an NFL career end,
but I had a backup plan. I went back to graduate school.
I was going to be an engineer.
